title: Racing's shame should unite industry
text:
As one of its biggest race days approaches, the racing sector cannot ignore concerns about the brutal mistreatment of retired racehorses.

It’s fitting that after a week spent engaged in predictable, parochial and puerile pissing contests about who has the biggest race meeting, horse racing authorities will be shocked back to reality by a confronting report on the mistreatment of the equine athletes at the heart of the industry.

The report on ABC Television’s 7.30 program suggested the industry’s attempts to limit “wastage” – that is, race horses being killed in abattoirs and knackers – are simply not working.

The images of unwanted race horses being slaughtered, including top performers on the track, identifiable by their implanted microchips, was confronting. The implication that thousands of race horses are dying this way – and not the tens of horses that the industry claims – must reverberate through the sector.

The predictable response from many racing people on social media last night was to explain how they love and care for retired race horses. It was the same response we saw last week, when former trainer Darren Weir was hit with animal cruelty charges, which go to court later this month.

Sorry, but it's just not enough.

No doubt there are many people in racing individually doing the right thing. But what’s been exposed is a systemic problem that demands the industry ask systemic questions and develop systemic responses.
